editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: As it was lately acted by her majesty's servants, at the phoenix in Drury lane.
London. Printed for John grove, and are to be sold at his shop at furnivalls inn gate in Holborn. 1629.

list.label: sir John Belfare.
Beauford, a passionate lover of Gratiana.
Marwood friend to Beauford.
Rawbone a thin citizen.
Lodam a fat gentleman.
justice Landby.
captain Landby.
Isaac, sir John's man.
Haver a young gentleman, lover of mistress Jane.
chameleon, Rawbone's man.
physician.
keeper.
surgeon.
servants.

div.head: To the right worshipful William Gowre, esquire.
div.p: Sir, I know you, and in that your worth, which I honour more than greatness in a patron: this comedy coming forth to take the air in summer, desireth to walk under your shadow. The world oweth a perpetual remembrance to your name, for excellency in the musical art of poesy, and your singular judgement and affection to it, have encouraged me to this dedication, in which I cannot transgress beyond your candour. It hath passed the stage; and I doubt not but from you, it shall receive a kind welcome, since you have been pleased to acknowledge the author.

div.head: To his learned and much respected friend, Mr. James Shirley, upon his wedding.
div.l: An enforced rapture, and high swelling phrase
Doth only gaudy ignorance amaze;
Conceits that yield judicious writers glory,
Enrich the beauty of thy comic story:
Love's passion in smooth numbers is descried,
Such as becomes the softness of a bride.
I want a poet's aery soul, to give
Due praises to thy lines, which shall outlive
The critic's spleen, the atheists impious jest;
A modest pen becomes the muses best,
And such is thine, as thy fair wedding shows,
Who crowns thee not, a debt to knowledge owes.

div.head: To his worthy friend Mr. Shirley, upon his nuptial comedy.
div.l: Is Beaumont dead? or slept he all this while,
To teach the world the want of his smooth style?
If he be dead, that part of him divine
By transmigration of his soul is thine:
High is thy fancy, yet thy strain so sweet,
Death would be loved in such a winding sheet:
This wedding needs no offering, and thy worth
Is above flattery, to set thee forth:
From whose rich muse thus wedded, we shall see
Many fair children born to poesy.

lg.l: Dies fugaci de siliunt pede
Nec urna cviquam parcit, at improbae
Vivit superstes fama morti,
Nec gelidum metuit sepulchrum.
O qui ingales flaws Hymen toros
Ambis, coruscâ iam nitidus togâ
Incede, ●hirlciana laurus,
Perpetuos tibi dat triumphos.
Phoebus sacrat● vellit ab arbore
Ramum, modestas quo decoret comas
Additque vatem laureatis
Sideribus, numerumque claudit.
Spread fair thou growing tree, with which in vain
The winds do wrest: blemished with the stain
Of impure life, some by atheistic rhymes,
And witty surfeits, force these ruder times
To fond amazement; but thy fair defence
Rests in clear art, and secure innocence.
As thou, thy muse is chaste, on which no rape
Was ere by thee committed, learning's ape
Is frantic imitation; and the bough
That crowns such writers, withers on their brow:
I gratulate thy wedding; love doth guide
My friendly muse, thus to salute thy bride.

div.head: To my deserving friend Mr. James Shirley, upon his comedy, the wedding.
div.l: Thou needest not, friend, that any man for thee,
Should to the world put in security.
Thy comedy is good; 'twill pass alone,
And fair enough, without this ribbons shown
Upon the forehead on't: if high raised passion
Tempered with harmless mirth, in such sweet fashion,
And with such harmony, as may invite
Two faculties of soul, and both delight
Deserve an approbation, in mine eye,
Such in just value is this comedy.

div.head: Of this ingenious comedy the wedding. To Mr. James Shirley the author.
div.l: The bonds are equal, and the marriage fit,
Where judgement is the bride, the husband wit;
Wit hath begotten, and judgement hath brought forth
A noble issue, of delight, and worth,
Grown in this comedy to such a strength
Of sweet perfection, as that not the length
Of days, nor rage of malice, can have force
To sue a nullity, or work divorce
Between this well trimmed wedding, and loud fame,
Which shall in every age, renew thy name.

div.head: Actus primi. Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter sir John Belfare, and Isaac his man, servants bringing in provision.

sp.speaker: Belfare.
sp.p: Well done my masters, ye bestir yourselves, I see we shall feast tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Your worship shall want no woodcocks at the wedding.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Thou hast as many as thou canst carry, and thirteen to the last dozen.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Have you been careful, to invite those friends, you had direction for?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
Yes sir, I have been a continual motion ever since I rise.
I have not said my prayers today.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: We shall want no guests then.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I have commanded most on 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I ha' bid 'em sir, there's two in my list, will not fail to dine w'ee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Master Rawbone, the young usurer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O he's reported a good trencherman,
He has a tall stomach, he shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: They say, he has made on obligation to the devil, if ever he eat a good meal at his own charge, his soul is forfeit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How does he live live?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Upon his money sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: He does not eat it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No the devil choke him, it were a golden age, if all the usurers in London should ha' no other diet; he has a thin-gut waits upon him, I think, one of his bastards, be got upon a spider, I hope to live, to see 'em both drawn through a ring.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Who is the other?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: The other may be known too, the barrel at Heidelberg was the pattern of his belly, master Lodam sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: He's a great man indeed.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Something given to the waste, for he lives within no reasonable compass I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: They will be well met.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: But very ill matched to draw a coach, yet at provender, there will be scarce an oat between the lean jade, and the fat gelding.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How lives he?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Religiously sir; for he that seeds well, must by consequence live well, he holds none can be damned but lean men, for fat men he says must needs be saved by the faith of their body.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Beauford, and captain Landby.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Mr. Beauford and captain Landby: Isaac, call forth my daughter.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Sir John, I hope you make no stranger of me,
Tomorrow, I shall change my title for
Your son, soon as the holy rites shall make me
The happy husband to your daughter, in the mean time
It will become me wait on her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I possess nothing but in trust for thee,
Gratiana makes all thine.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I shall presume to follow.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your friendship noble captain to Mr. Beauford,
Makes your person most welcome,
Had you no other merit, pray enter. Exe. Bea. and Cap.
Heaven hath already crowned my grey hairs!
I live to see my daughter married
To a noble husband, the envy of our time,
And exact pattern of a gentleman,
As hopeful as the spring, I am grown proud,
Even in my age. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dost hear sirrah?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is master Beauford within?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I was informed he came hither, is he not here?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou sayst he's not within.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: No sir, but 'tis very like he will be tomorrow night sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: Would you have him be within before he is married.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Witty groom, prithee invite him forth; say here's a friend

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Now you talk of inviting, I have two or three guests to invite yet: let me see.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why dost not move?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: And you make much ado, I'll invite you: pray come to the ▪ wedding tomorrow. Exit.

div.stage: Enter sir John Belfare, Beauford, and captain.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis he.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: You were my happy prospect from the window, coz you are a most welcome guest.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Mr. Marwood, you have been a great stranger to the city, or my house for the course entertainment you received, hath been unworthy of your visit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Twas much above my desert sir: captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I congratulate your return.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Beauford, gentlemen enter my house,
And perfect your embraces there: I lead the way. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Pray follow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your pardon.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: We know you have other habit,
You were not wont to affect ceremony. Mar. and Bea whisper.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I do not like his present countenance,
It does threaten somewhat; I would not prophesy.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Good captain,
Excuse my absence to our friends within,
I have affairs concerns me with my kinsman,
Which done, we both return to wait on 'em.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Now proceed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We are kinsmen.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: More we are friends.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And shall I doubt to speak to Beauford any thing,
My love directs me to?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What needs this circumstance?
We were not wont to talk at such a distance,
You appear wild.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I have been wild indeed
In my ungoverned youth, but ha' reclaimed it,
And am to laden with the memory of former errors,
That I desire to be confessed.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Confessed? I am no ghostly father.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But you must hear, you may absolve me too:

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: If thou hast any discontentments prithee take other time
For their discourse, I am in expectation of marriage,
I would not interrupt my joys.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I must require your present hearing,
'A concerns us both, as near as fame, or life.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ha! what is it?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: We shall have opportunity at your lodging,
The streets are populous and full noise,
So please you walk, I'll wait one you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I'm your servant. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Milisent. Where's my daughter?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: In compliment with Mr. Rawbone, who is newly entered sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: O there's a piece of folly.
A thing made up of parchment and his bonds
Are of more value than his soul and body,
Were any man the purchaser, only wise
In his hereditary trade of usury,
Understands nothing but a scrivener,
As if he were created for no use
But to grow rich with interest, to his ignorance,
He has the gift, of being impudent,
What will he grow to, if he live, that is
So young a monster?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: With your favour sir
If you hold no better opinion of this citizen
It puzzles, me why you invite him, to your house
And entertainment, he pretending affection to your daughter,
Pardon me sir if I seem bold.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: As some men Milisent
Do suffer spiders in their chamber, while
They count them profitable vermin.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But he's most like to scatter poison sir,
Your fame is precious, and your family
not mingling with corrupted streams, hath like
An entire river, still maintained his current
Chaste, and delightful.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Shalt receive my bosom,
I'll sooner match her with an Aethiop,
Then give consent, she should disgrace our blood;
And herein I but try her strength of judgement
In giving him access; if she have lost
Remembrance of her birth, and generous thoughts ▪
She sucked from her dead mother, with my care
I'll strive to reinforce her native goodness,
Or quite divorce her from my blood: and Milisent
I'll use your vigilance.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Sir command.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I will,
Not urge how I received you first a stranger,
Nor the condition of your life, with me,
Above the nature of a servant, to
Oblige your faith: I have observed thee honest.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You are full of noble thoughts.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Though I suspect not
The obedience of my daughter, yet her youth
Is apt to err, let me employ your eye
Upon her still, and receive knowledge from you,
How she dispenceth favours, you shall bind
My love the stronger to you.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Sir, I shall be ambitions to deserve your favour
Withal the duties of a servant, and
I doubt not, but your daughter is so full
Of conscience, and care in the conformity
Of her desires to your will, I shall
Enrich my sight with observation,
And make my intelligence happy.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: How now: what's he?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: 'Tis Mr. Rawbone's squire.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pray is not my master's worship here?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Your master's worship!
What's that, his spaniel?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No sir, but a thing that does follow him.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: In what likeness,
I hope he does not converse with spirits.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He'll not entertain an angel,
But he will weigh him first, indeed
I am all the spirits that belong to him.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: So I think, but none of his familiar.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Chameleon.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Good; didst ever eat?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes once.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: And than thou caught'st a surfeit,
Thou couldst ne'er endure meat since: were't ever christened.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes twice, first in my infancy,
And the last time about a year ago,
When I should have been prentice to an Anabaptist.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Does thy master love thee?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, for, and I would gold I might have it,
But my stomach would better digest beef, or mutton,
If there be any such things in nature.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Here is his master sir, and mistress Jane.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: How now chameleon, hast dined?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes sir,
I had a delicate fresh air to dinner.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: And yet thou lookest as thou hadst eat nothing this se'night, here provide me a capon, and half a dozen of pigeons to supper, and when will your worship come home, and taste my hospitality.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: When you please sir,

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Yet now I think on't,
I must feed more sparingly.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: More liberally in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Would not anybody in the world think so? did you ever see two such earwigs as my man and I: do we not look like.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: I think the picture of either o'your faces in a ring, with a memento mors, would be as sufficient a mortification, as lying with an anatomy.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: The reason why we are so lean and consumed, is nothing, but eating too much: chameleon now I think on't, let the pigeons alone, the capon will be enough for thee and I.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The rump would last us a se'night.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I tell you forsooth, I ha' brought myself so low, with a great diet, that I must be temperate, or the doctor says there's no way but one wi'me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: That's not the way of all flesh I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: It is a shame to say, what we eat every day.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: By this hand: if it would bear an oath: we have had nothing this two days but half a lark; which by a mischance the cat had killed too, the cage being open: I will provide my belly another master.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Now I'll interrupt 'em master Rawbone.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I hope your worship will repinie my boldness,
'Tis out of love to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Sir, I have a business to you, a friend of mine upon some necessity would take up a hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I'll pawn some ounces to pleasure him.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: It is more friendly said than I expected.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: So he bring me good security, some three or
Four, or five sufficient and able citizens, for
Mortality's sake, I'll lend it him.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Will you not take an honest man's word.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Few words to the wise, I will take any man's word to owe me a hundred pound, but not a lord's to pay me fifty.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Well: 'tis courtesy.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: He shall pay nothing to me but lawful consideration from time to time, beside the charges of th'ensealing, because he is your friend.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: This is extremity, can you require more?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: More? what's eight in the hundred to me? my scriveners knows, I have taken forty and fifty in the hundred vijs and modis of my own kinsmen, when they were in necessity.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I apprehend the favour.
How now Isaac?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: My master commends his love to you sir, and does desire your presence together with your daughter and nephew, at the arraignment of my young mistress tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: How knave?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: She is to be married or arraigned, ith' morning, and at night to suffer execution and lose her head.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Return our thanks, and say we'll wait upon the bride Jane. Exeunt justice and Jane.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Dear master Rawbone, I do beseech you be at these sessions.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Thou didst invite me before.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: I know it, but our cock has a great mind, that sentence should likewise pass upon the roast, the boiled, and the baked, and he fears unless you be a commissioner, the meat will hardly be condemned tomorrow, so that I can never often enough desire your stomach to remember, you will come.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Dost think I won't keep my word?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Alas, we have nothing, but good cheer to entertain you, I beseech you sir howsoever to feast with us, though you go away after dinner.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: There's my hand —

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Is master justice gone, and mistress Jane too? follow me chameleon. I'll take my leave when I come again.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: My little wit, thou wilt come with thy master tomorrow, I'll reserve a bottle of wine to warm thy sconce.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I cannot promise.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
If I durst stay three minutes, I would venture a cup with thee ith' buttery, but 'tis a busy time at home:
Farewell Milisent. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Marriage as much joy wait upon the bride,
As the remembrance of it brings me sorrow,
A woman has undone me, when I die
A coffin will enclose this misery. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You prepare me for some wonder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do:
And ere I come to the period of my story,
Your understanding will admire.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Teach my soul the way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am not coz ith' number of those friends
Come to congratulate your present marriage.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am no flatterer, the blood you carry
Doth warm my veins, yet could nature be
Forgetful and remove itself, the love
I owe your merit, doth oblige me, to
Relation of a truth which else would fire
My bosom with concealment. I am come
To divide your s●u●e, ravish all your pleasures,
Poison the very air maintains your breathing,
You must not marry.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Must not? though as I
Am mortal I may be compelled within
a pair of minutes to turn ashes, yet
My soul already bridegroom to her virtue,
Shall laugh at death that would unmarry us,
And call her mine eternally.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Death is
A mockery to that divorce I bring,
Come you must not love her.

sp.speaker: Beau,
sp.l: Did I hope thou couldst
Give me a reason, I would ask one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do not,
I will too soon arrive, and make you curse
Your knowledge, couldst exchange thy temper for
An angels ▪ at the hearing of this reason,
'Twould make you passionate, and turn man again.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Can there be reason for a sin so great,
As changing my affection from Gratiana?
Name it, and reach me how to be a monster,
For I must lose humanity ▪ o Marwood,
Thou leadest me into a wilderness, she is —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: False, sinful, a black soul she has.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou hast a hell about thee, and thy language
Speaks thee a devil, that to blast her innocence
Dost belch these vapours: to say thou liest,
Were to admit, thou hast but made in this
A humane error, when thy sin hath aimed
The fall of goodness. Gratiana false?
The snow shall turn a salamander first
And dwell in fire; the air retreat, and leave
An emptiness in nature, angels be
Corrupt, and bribed by mortals sell their charity
Her innocence is such, that wert thou Marwood
For this offence condemned to lodge in flames,
It would for ever cure thy burning fever,
If with thy sorrow thou procure her shed
One tear upon thee, now, thou art lost for ever,
and armed thus, though with thousand furies guarded,
I reach thy heart. Draws:

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: Stay Beauford,
Since you dare be so confident of her chastity
Hear me conclude, I bring no idle fable
Patched up between suspicion, and report
Of scandalous tongues, my ears were no assurance
To convince me without my eyes.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What horror!
Be more particular:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I did prophesy,
That it would come to this, for I have had
A tedious struggling with my nature, but
The name of friend o'erbalanced the exception:
Forgive me ladies, that my love to man
Hath power to make me guilty of such language,
As with it, must betray a woman's honour:

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You torture me, be brief.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then, though it carry shame to the reporters,
Forgive me heaven, and witness an unwelcome truth.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Stay, I am too hasty for the knowledge
Of something thou preparest for my destruction,
May I not think what 'tis, and kill myself?
Or at least by degrees, with apprehending
Some strange thing done, infect my fancy with
Opinion first, and so dispose myself
To death? I cannot, when I think of Gratiana
I entertain a heaven: the worst, I'll hear it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It will enlarge itself too soon, receive it;
I have enjoyed her.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gratiana sinfully, before your love
Made she and you acquainted.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ha? thou'st kept thy word thou canst so poison all
My comfort ▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your friendship I ha' preferred
To my own fame, and but to save you from
A lasting shipwreck, noble Beauford, think
It should have rotted here, she that will part
With virgin honour, ne'er should wed the heart.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Was ever woman good, and Gratiana
Vicious? lost to honour? at the instant
When I expected all my harvest ripe.
The golden summer tempting me to reap
The well grown ears, comes an impetuous storm
Destroys an ages hope in a short minute,
And lets me live, the copy of man's frailty:
Surely, some one of all the female sex,
Engrossed the virtues, and fled hence to heaven,
Left womankind dissemblers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, make use
Of reason, 'tis a knowledge should rejoice you,
Since it does teach you to preserve yourself.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Enjoyed Gratiana sinfully, 'tis a sound
Able to kill with horror; it infects
The very air, I see it like a mist
Dwell round about, that I could uncreate
Myself, or be forgotten, no remembrance
That ever I loved woman: I have no
Genius left to instruct me — it grows late:
Within —
Wait o'my kinsman to his chamber,
I shall desire your rest, pray give me leave
To think a little —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Cousin: I repent
I have been so open breasted, since you make
This severe use on't, and afflict your mind
With womanish sorrow, I have but cautioned you
Against a danger, out of my true friendship:
Prosper me goodness as my ends are noble ▪
goodnight, collect yourself, and be a man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And why may not a kinsman be a villain?
Perhaps he loves Gratiana, and envying
My happiness, doth now traduce her chastity
To find this out, time will allow but narrow
Limits: his last words bade me be a man.
A man? yes I have my soul, t'does not become
A manly resolution to be tame thus,
And give up the opinion of his mistress
For one man's accusat on; — ha: ith' morning?
Proper. Yes Marwood I will be a man:
His 〈◊〉 d, shall either make passed the sense
Of this affliction. or mine enforce
A truth from him, if thou beest wronged Gratiana
I'll ye thy martyr, but if false, in this
I gain to ●ye, not hue a sacrifice. Exit.

div.head: Actus secundi. Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: To the tailor's man, run.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: To the tailor's man,
Why not to his master?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The wedding clothes not brought
Home yet, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Who would trust of woman's tailor, take measure so long before of a gentlewoman, and not bring home his commodity, there's no conscience in't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The arrant shoemaker too.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Master hide, is not he, come yet I called upon him yesterday, to make haste of my mistress's shoes, and he told me, he was about the upper leather, he would be at her heels presently, I left his foot in the stirrup, I thought he would have rid post after me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Prithee Isaac, make haste, how tedious thou'rt, hast not thou been there yet.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: O yes, and here again, d'ye not see me, you are so light yourself.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As thou goest, call upon cod the perfumer, tell him he uses us sweetly, has not brought home the gloves yet. — and dost hear? when thou'rt at the peacock remember to call for the sprig, by the same token I left my fan to be mended: — and dost hear? when thou'rt there, 'tis but a little out of the way, to run to the devil, and bid the vintner make haste with the runlets of claret, we shall ha' no time to burn it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You need not if it come from devil, methinks that wine should burn itself.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Run I prithee.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Tailors, shoemakers, perfumers, feather-makers, and the devil and all, what a many occupations does a woman run through, before she is married. Exit.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Fie upon't what a perplexity is about a wedding, I might have been thus troubled for a child of my own, if good luck had served.

lg.l: — Within. Cardona.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I come ladybird. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Was this your purpose.

sp.speaker: Bea,
sp.l: This place of all the park affords most privacy.
Nature has placed the trees to imitate
A Roman amphitheatre.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We must be the sword-players.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Draw, imagine all
These trees were cypress, the companions of
Our funeral, for one or both must go
To a dark habitation, methinks
We two, are like to some unguided men,
That having wandered all the day in a
Wild unknown path, at night walk down into
A hollow grot, a cave which never star
Durst look into, made in contempt of light
By nature, which the moon did never yet
Befriend with any melancholy beam:
O cousin thou hast led me, where I never
Shall see day move.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is the way to make it
A night indeed, but if you recollect
Yourself, I brought you beams to let you see
The horror of that darkness you are going to,
By marrying with Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: That name
Awakes my resolution, consume not
Thy breath too idly, thou'st but a small time
For th'use of't, either employ it in the unsaying
Thy wrong to Gratiana, or thou hastens
Thy last minute.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I must tell Beauford them,
He is ungrateful to return so ill
My friendship, have I undervalued
My shame in the relation of a truth,
To make the man I wooed preserve, my enemy:
Why dost thou tempt thy destiny with so
Much sin? dost think I were a sword I dare
Not manage? or that I can be enforced
to a revolt? I am no rebel Beauford:
Again I must confirm Gratiana's honour
Stained, the treasures of her chastity
Rifled, and lost, 'twas my unhappiness
To have added that, unto my other sinnes
Ith' wildness of my blood, which thou mayst punish.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou hast repeated, but the same in
Substance touching Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Truth is ever constant
Reimains upon her square, firm, and unshaken.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: If what thou hast affirmed be true, why should
We fight, be cruel to ourselves, endanger
Our eternity, for the error of
One frail woman? Let our swords expect
A nobler cause. What man hath such assurance
In any woman's faith, that he should run
A desperate hazard of his soul? I know
Women are not born angels, but created
With passion and temper like to us,
And men are apt to err, and louse themselves
Caught with the soul of wanton beauty, fettered
Even with their mistress's hair

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I like this well.Aside.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: He has a handsome presence and discourse,
Two subtle charms to tempt a woman's frailty,
Who must be governed by their eye or ear
To love, beside my kinsman hath been taxed.
For being too prompt in wantonness, this confirms it
Then farewell woman kind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This does become you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Why should we fight, our letting blood wo'not
Cure her, and make her honour white again:
We are friends, repent thy sin, and marry her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How sir, marry her?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Why canst though add to it another crime,
By a refusing to repair the ruins
Of that chaste temple, thou hadst violated?
Her virgin tapers are by thee extinct,
No odour of her chastity, which once
Gave a perfume to heaven, and and did refresh
Her innocent soul, they that have spoilt virginity,
Do half restore the treasures they took thence
By sacred marriage.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Marriage, with whom?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Should I marry a whore?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou liest, and with a guilt upon thy soul,
Able to sink thee to damnation,Draws again.
I'll send thee hence; a whore? what woman
Was ever bad enough to deserve that name?
Salute some native fury, or a wretch
Condemned already to hell's tortures by it,
Not Gratiana; thou'st awakened justice,
And given it eyes to see thy treachery,
The depth of thy malicious heart, that word, hath
Disenchanted me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are you serious?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How have I fined in my credulity
'Gainst virtue, all this while? what charm bound up
My understanding part, I should admit
A possibility, for her to carry
So black a soul; though all her sex beside
Had fallen from their creation? thou hast
Not life enough to forfeit, what an advantage
To fame and goodness had been lost.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will you fight?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Wert thou defenced with circular fire, more
Subtle than the lightning, that I knew would ravish
my heart, and marrow from me, yet I should
Neglect the danger, and but singly armed,
Fly to revenge thy calumny: a whore — come on sir.
Thou'rt wounded: ha? Fight.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mortally, fly Beauford, save thyself, I hasten to the dead.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: O stay a while, or thou wilt lose us both,
Thy wound I cannot call back, now there is
No dallying with heaven, but thou pull'st on thee
Double confusion, leave a truth behind thee,
As thou wouldst hope rest to thy parting soul,
Hast thou not wronged Gratiana?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, in my lust, but not in my report,
Take my last breath, I sinfully enjoyed her,One hollows within.
Gratiana is a blotted piece of alabaster:
Farewell lest some betray thee, heaven forgive
My offence, as I do freely pardon thine.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I cannot long survive, —
Is there no hope thou mayst recover?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Farewell for ever then, with thy short breath
May all thy ills conclude, mine but begin
To muster, life and I shall quickly part,
I feel a sorrow will break Beauford's heart. Exit.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There are coney-stealers abroad sir.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: These whoreson rabbit suckers
Will ne'er leave the ground.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: In my walk last night, I frighted some on 'em.
Pox a these vermin, would they were all destroyed.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: So we may chance to keep no deer.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: An old coney stops a knave's mouth sometimes.
That else would be gaping for venison.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Here's a gentleman wounded.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: He has bled much.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: How came you hurt sir? no,
Not speak? if he be not past hope, let us
Carry him to my lodge ▪ my wife is a
Piece of a surgeon, has been fortunate
In some cures: tear a piece of thy shirt Raph,
To bind his wound quickly: — so, so, alas
Poor gentleman, he may hue to be dressed, and tell
Who has done this misfortune: gentlyExe. carry him in.
Honest Raph, he has some breath yet:
Would ● had my bloodhound here.

div.stage: Enter sir John Belfare justice Landby, and his daughter Jane ▪ Isaac waiting.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You're welcome Mr. Landby, and mistress Jane.
Where's the young captain sir your nephew?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: He went betimes to wait upon the bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: They are inseparable friends, as they had
Divided hearts, they both are glad, when either
Meet a good fortune.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I'll be bold to see your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Do mistress Jane, she has
Her maids blush yet, she'll make you amends for this,
And ere't be long I hope 'Dance at your wedding. Exit Jane.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I wish you many joy's sir by this marriage:
Your daughter ha' made discreet election,
She'll have a hopeful gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Master Landby,
It would refresh my age to see her fruitful to him,
I should find a blessing for a young
Beauford, and be glad to dandle him, the
First news of a boy born by my daughter
Would set me back seven years: oh master Landby,
old men do never truly dote, until
Their children bring 'em babies.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Rawbone, and Haver as his servant.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Master Rawbone ▪ I'll be bold to present you
With a piece of rosemary, we ha' such cheer.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Honest Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Pray do you belong to master Rawbone?

sp.speaker: Hau
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You have eat something in your days.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Why prithee?

sp.speaker: Isa
sp.l: Nothing, nothing,
D'ye understand nothing, you shall eat nothing:
Unless some benefactors like my master,
In pity of your bellies once a year
Do warm it with a dinner, you must never
Hope to see roast, of sod; he has within
This twelvemonth to my knowledge
Made seven men immortal.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Yes, he has made spirits on 'em,
And they haunt such men's houses as my masters,
Spirits ath' buttery, let me counsel ye
To cram your corpses today, for by his almanac
There's a long lent a coming.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Never see me,
But when you are invited.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Alas I had
Rather eat a piece of cold capon at home,
Than be troublesome abroad. I hope forsooth
Mistress Jane is as she should be.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: She is in health:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You've a fresh servant master Rawbone,
A proper fellow, and maintains himself
Handsomely.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: And he would not ha' maintained
himself, I had never entertained him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Where's chameleon?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I ha' preferred him Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Turned him away last night,
And took this stripling.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Morrow sir John, where is the early bridegroom?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Came not you from him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We expect him sir, every minute.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Not yet come? his servants ▪ told me
He went abroad before the morning blushed.

sp.speaker: Rel.
sp.l: We ha' not seen him, pray heaven
He be in health.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I wonder at his absence.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Captain Landby, young man of war, I do
Salute thee with a broadside.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: D'ye hear, they
Say you come a-wooing to my cousin,
That day you marry her, I'll cut your throat,
Keep't to yourself.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Thou art a noble fellow; things may prosper.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You come hither to wish c●n give 'em joy now.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Yes marry do I.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You do lie, you come to
Scour your dirty maw with the good cheer,
Which will be damned in your lean barathrum,
That kitchen-stuff devourer.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Why should you
Say so captain? my belly did ne'er think
You any harm.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: When it does vomit up thy heart
I'll praise it, in the mean time would
Every bit thou eatst today, were steeped
In aqua fortis.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: What is that Jasper?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: It is strong water.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Noble captain, thanks i'faith heartily:
I was afraid you had been angry.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'll ha' thee sowed up in a
Moneybag, and boiled to jelly.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: You shall ha' me at your service,
And my bags too, upon good security:
Is not this better than quarrelling, Jasper, —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is not the bridegroom come yet, sure he has over slept himself, there is nothing but wondering within, all the maids are in uproar, one says he is a slow thing, another says, she knows not what to say, but they all conclude, if ever they marry, they'll make it in their bargain to be sure of all things before matrimony, fie upon him, if I were to be his wife, I'd show him a trick for't, ere a year came about, or it should cost me a fall, I warrant him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Sir John you're troubled.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Can you blame me sir:
I would not have our morning's expectation
Frustrate — I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Sir, fear not.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The morn grows old.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Hymen has long tapers.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What should procure his absence; he departed
But oddly yesterday.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Marwood had engaged him,
They promised to return.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But we see neither.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: They'll come together, make it not your fear,
Beaufords a gentleman, and cannot be
Guilty of doing such affront, unless
Some misfortune —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: That's another jealousy.

div.stage: Enter Lodam, Cameleon waiting upon him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Where is sir John Belfare?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ha? Master Lodam,
Welcome.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I congratulate. —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Saw you master Beauford sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes I saw him, but —

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know not how he does,
Where is the lady that must be undone tonight ,
Your daughter?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My daughter undone, name what unhappiness,
My heart already doth begin to prophesy
How 〈…〉, name what disaster, give it
Expression pray, what is the news?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The news?
Why would ye know the news? 'tis none a'ch best.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Be temperate then in your relation.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: They say for certain,
There were four and twenty colliers cast away,
Coming from Newcastle 'tis cold news ith' city,
But there is worse news abroad.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Doth it concern my knowledge? trifle not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: They say that canary sack, must dance
Again to the apothecaries, and be sold for
Physic, in hum-glasses, and thimbles ▪ that the
Spaw-water must be transported hither, and
Be drunk instead of French wines:
For my part, I am but one.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Big enough for two.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This citadel may endure as long a siege
As another, if the pride of my flesh must be
Pulled down, farewell it t'has done me
service this forty year: let it go.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Saw you master Beauford?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes sir John,
I saw him but — 'twas three days ago.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: He is ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Do not afflict yourself,
He will give a fair account at his return.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pray heaven he may:
My daughter.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Sir, I desire to be acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I have no stomach sir to your acquaintance,
You are a thought too lean.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: And you a bit too fat.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dost not wonder girl at Beauford's absence?

sp.speaker: Grats.
sp.l: Not at all sir, I am not now to learn
Opinion of his nobleness; and I hope
Your judgements will not permit you sin so much
To censure him for this stay. Fair morning
To master Landby, noble captain, master
Lodam, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I am so little
She cannot see me, give you joy forsooth,
I hope it is your destiny to be married.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And yours to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: How sir.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: No harm,
He wishes you long life.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: A long halter he does,
What to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: 'Las sir he knows you ha' no flesh to burden you,
Light at a feather, hanging will ne'er kill you,
If he had wished sir master Lodam hanged.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Then, I'll to him and thank him;
But here's mistress Jane.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You shall command me as your servant. — sirrah. Exit. As he goes out, he sees Rawb. court Jane.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I did but ask her how she did, I said
Never a word to her: pox upon his bouncing
I am as fearful of him as of a gun,
He does so powder me.

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: We have not seen
You sir, this great while, you fall away methinks.

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.l: Losing Lodam I.

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: You are not the least welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I do give you great thank, and do mean to dance at your wedding for't, I do marvel master Beauford is not earlier, I should ha' been here with music lady, and have fiddled you too, before you were up, these lean lovers, ha' nothing in 'em, slow men of London.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Gratiana. Lod spies Jane.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Who's this? she has a mortal eye.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Chameleon? How now turned away your master.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No, I sold my place; as I was thinking to run away, comes this fellow, and offered me a breakfast for my good will to speak to my master for him, I took him at his word, and resigned my office, and turned over my hunger to him immediately; now I serve a man, Isaac.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Isaac. —Exit Isaac as sent off.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I do foresee a fall of this tower already,
Love begins to undermine it.
Mistress, a word in private.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Jasper hast a sword.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: That's well, let it alone:
Didst see this paunch affront me?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: He did it in love to the gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: In love? let me see the sword again. Draws.
Would 'twere in his belly — put it up,
Thou deservest a good blade, 'tis so well kept.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Master Beauford, master Beauford.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Hard by, within a stone's cast a my
Mistress, here sit here. Enter Beauford.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: My dearest Beauford, where hast been so long?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Are you not in health?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Not well, 'tis then no time to chide:
How fare you sir?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I have a trouble at my heart: pardon
The trespass of your patience gentlemen,
He publish the occasion of my absence,
So first, you give me leave, to unlade it here;
But with your favour, I desire I may
Exempt all ears, but Gratiana's, till
A short time ripen it for your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Let's leave 'em then a while.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Into the garden gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Withal my heart:
In my conscience the 'I'll be honest together.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This begets my wonder, master Lodam.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good sir John, I'll wait upon you,
It is dinner time. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I have not time to dwell on circumstance,
I come to take my last leave, you and I
Must never meet again.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What language do I hear,
If Beauford it should strike me dead?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: This day, I had designed for marriage, but I must
Pronounce we are eternally divorced:
O Gratiana, thou hast made a wound
Beyond the cure of surgery, why did nature
Empty her treasure in thy face, and leave thee
A black prodigious soul?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Defend me goodness!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Call upon darkness, to obscure thee rather,
That never more thou mayst be seen by mortal,
Get thee some dwelling in a mist, or in
A wild forsaken earth, a wilderness,
Where thou mayst hide thyself, and die forgotten.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Where was I lost name what offence provoked
This heavy doom, dear Beauford, be not so
Injust, to sentence me, before I know
What is my crime, or if you will not tell
What sin it is, I have committed, great,
And horrid, as your anger; let me study,
I'll count 'em all before you, never did
Penitent, in confession, strip the soul
More naked, I'll unclasp my book of conscience,
You shall read o'er my heart, and if you find
In that great volume, but one single thought
Which concerned you, and did not end with some
Good prayer for you: o be just and kill me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Be just, and tell thy conscience, thou'st abused it
False woman, why dost thou increase thy horror?
By the obscuring a misdeed, which would
Were all thy other sins forgiven, undo thee
O Gratiana, thou art. —

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What am I?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: A thing I would not name, it sound so fearfully,
'Twould make a devil blush, to be saluted
By that, which thou must answer to.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I fear —

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: That fear betrays thy guilt, tell me Gratiana
What didst thou see in me to make thee think
I was not worthy of thee, at thy best
And richest value, when thou were as white
In soul, as beauty? for sure, once thou wert so:
Hadst thou so cheap opinion of my birth,
My breeding, or my fortunes, that none else
could serve for property of your lust, but I?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Dear Beauford hear me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: A common father to thy sin-got issue,
A patron of thy rifled, unchaste womb?
O thou wert cruel, to reward so ill
The heart that truly honoured thee: thy name
Which sweetened once the breath of him that spoke it,
And musically charmed the gentle ear;
Shall sound hereafter like a screech-owl's note,
And fright the hearer; virgins shall lament
That thou hast shamed their chaste society,
And oft as Hymen lights his tapers up,
At the remembrance of thy name, shed tears,
And blush for thy dishonour: from this minute,
Thy friends shall count thee desperately sick,
And whensoe'er thou goest abroad, that day
The maids and matrons, thinking thou art dead,
And going to the grave, shall all come forth
And wait like mourners on thee.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Ha ye done?
Then hear me a few syllables, you have
Suspicion that I am dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: No,
By heaven I have not, I have too much knowledge
To suspect thee sinful, but in the assurance
Of it, I must disclaim thy heart for ever:
Gratiana my opinion of thy whiteness
Hath made my soul, as black as thine already;
Weep till thou wash away thy stain, and then,
Ith' other world, we two, may meet again. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Weep inward eyes, hither your streams impart,
For sure, I have tears enough, to drown my heart. Exit.

div.head: Actus tertij. Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You amaze me Beauford, Gratiana false?
I shall suspect the truth of my conception,
And think all women monsters, though I never
Loved with that nearness of affection
To marry any, yet I mourn they should
Fall from their virtue, why may not Marwood
Injure her goodness?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What, and dam his soul?
Shall I think any with his dying breath
Would shipwreck his last hope? he mixed it with
His prayers, when in the stream of his own blood,
His soul was launching forth.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: That circumstance takes away all suspicion again,
Where left you Marwood?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I'the park.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Quite dead?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Hopeless, his weapon might have proved so happy,
To have released me of a burden too;
And but that manhood, and the care of my
Eternity forbids, I would force out
That which but wearies me to carry it,
Unwelcome life?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Would he were buried,
my fears perplex me for you; though none see
You fight, the circumstance must needs
Betray you: what's he. Enter a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I would borrow your ear in private.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: We are but one to hear, his love hath
Made him? to great a part of my affliction:
Speak it.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: The body is taken thence.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I cannot be deceived sir: I beheld
Too plain a demonstration of the place;
But he that suffered such a loss of blood,
Had not enough to maintain life till this time,
Which way soe'er his body was conveyed:
I must conclude it short lived, I am sorry
I could not serve you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Sir, — I thank you,
You deserve I should be grateful:Gives him money.
It must be so —Exit surgeon.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: What fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: A surgeon.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Dare you trust him?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Yes, with my life.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You have done that already in your discovery.
Pray heaven he prove your friend.
You must resolve for flight, ye shall take ship —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Will you ruin yourself? there's no security —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: There is not captain,
Therefore I'll not change my air.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Unless thou canst instruct me how to fly from
Myself, for wheresoever else I wander,
I shall but carry my accuser with me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I have heard in Afric, is a tree, which tasted
by travellers, it breeds forgetfulness
Of their country, canst direct me thither?
Yet 'twere in vain, unless it can extinguish,
And drown the remembrance I am Beauford:
No — I'll not move, let those poor things that dare not
Die, obey their fears, I will expect my fate here.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: This is wildness,
A desperate folly, pray be sensible: —
Who's this, 'tis Gratiana.

div.stage: Enter Gratiana with a cabinet of jewels.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ha, farewell.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You shall stay now a little.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I will not hear an accent, I shall lose
My memory, be charmed into belief
That she is honest with her voice, I dare not
Trust my frailty with her.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: She speaks nothing,
Is all a weeping Niobe, a statue,
Or in this posture, doth she not present
A water nymph ▪ placed in the midst of some
Fair garden, like a fountain to dispense
Her crystal streams upon the flowers? which cannot
But so refreshed, look up, and seem to smile
Upon the eyes that feed 'em:
Will she speak?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Though by the effusion of my tears, you may
Conclude, I bring nothing but sorrow with me,
Yet hear me speak, I come not to disturb
Your thoughts, or with one bold and daring language
Say how unjust you make my sufferings:
I know not what
Hath raised this mighty storm to my destruction,
But I obey your doom, and after this,
Will never see you more. First I release
And give you back your vows; with them, your heart ▪
which I had locked up in my own, and cherished
Better, mine I'm sure does bleed to part with't,
All that is left of yours, this cabinet
Delivers back to your possession,
There's every jewel you bestowed upon me,
The pledges once of love.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Pray keep 'em.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: They are not mine, since I have lost the opinion
Of what I was, indeed I have nothing else,
I would not keep the kisses, once you gave me,
If you would let me pay them back again.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: All women is a labyrinth, we can,
Measure the height of any star, point out
All the dimensions of the earth, examine
The seas large womb, and sounds its subtle depth,
But art will ne'er be able to find out,
A demonstration of a woman's heart,
Thou hast enough undone me, make me not
More miserable, to believe thou canst be virtuous:
Farewell, enjoy you this, I shall find out
Another room to weep in. Exit.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Lady I would ask you a rude question:
Are you a maid?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Do I appear so monstrous? no man will
Believe my injury: has heaven forgotten
To protect innocence, that all this while
It hath vouchsafed no miracle, to confirm
A virgin's honour?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I am answered:
I do believe she's honest; o that I could
But speak with Marwood's ghost now, and thou beest
In hell, I'd meet thee half way, to converse
One quarter of an hour with thee, to know
The truth of all things, thy devil jailer
May trust thee without a waiter, he has security
for thy damnation in this sin alone,
I me full of pity now, and spite of manhood
Cannot forbear, come lady, I am confident,
I know not which way — that you're virtuous —
Pray walk with me, I'll tell you the whole story;
For yet you know not your accuser.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I am an exile hence, and cannot walk
Out of my way, Beauford farewell, may angels
Dwell round about thee, live until thou find,
When I am dead, thou hast been too unkind. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: May I believe thee Milisent, that my father
Though he give such respect to him I hate,
Intends no marriage? thou hast released
My heart of many fears, that I was destined
To be a sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: It had been sin
That Milisent should suffer you perplex
Your noble soul, when it did consist in
His discovery, to give a freedom
To your labouring thoughts, 'tis now no more a secret,
Your father makes a trial of your nature,
By giving him such countenance.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: What thanks shall I give?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Your virtue hath both unsealed
My bosom, and rewarded me.

sp.speaker: Jane
sp.l: O Milisent:
Thou hast deserved my gratitude; and I cannot
But in exchange of thy discovery
Give to thy knowledge, what I should tremble
To let another hear; for I dare trust thee with it.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: If I have any skill
In my own nature, shall ne'er deceive
your confidence, and think myself much honoured,
So to be made your treasurer.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: 'Tis a treasure,
And all the wealth I have, my life, the sum
Of all my joys on earth, and the expectation
Of future blessings too depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Can I be worthy of so great a trust?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Thou art, and shalt receive it, for my heart
Is willing to discharge itself into thee:
O Milisent! though my father would ha' been
So cruel to his own, to have wished me marry
Him, 'twas not in the power of me obedience
To give consent to't, for my love already
Is dedicate to one, whose worth hath made
Me, but his steward of it, and although
His present fortune doth eclipse his lustre,
With seeming condition of a servant,
He has a mind derived from honour, and
May boast himself a gentleman: is not
Thy understanding guilty of the person
I point at? Sure thou canst not choose but know him.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Then look upon him Milisent.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: My master, mistress Jane sent me before,
To say, be comes to visit you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: But thou art before him in acceptance, nay
You stand discovered here, in Milisent you may
Repose safe trust.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Her language makes me confident,
You are a friend.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: To both a servant.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: I shall desire your love.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: But where's this man of mortgages?
We shall be troubled now

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: I left him chawing the cud, ruminating
Some speech or other, with which, he means to
Arrest you.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He is entered.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I have prepared her.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Fortune be my guide then.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: And she's a blind one.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p:
Mistress Jane, I would talk with you in private, I have fancied a business, I know you are witty, and love invention, 'tis my own, and nobody else must hear it —
Be it known to all men by these presents.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: This is like to be a secret.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: That I Jasper Rawbone citizen, and housekeeper of London.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: A very poor one I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Do owe to mistress Jane, lady of my thoughts, late of London gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Is she not still a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Still a gentlewoman goodman coxcomb? did I not say she was lady of my thoughts? where was I now?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: At goodman coxcomb sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: — Do owe to mistress Jane, lady of my thoughts, late of London gentlewoman, my true and lawful heart of England — to be paid to his said mistress, her executors, or assigns.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: To her executors? what will you pay your heart, when she is dead?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: 'Tis none of my fault, and she will die, who can help it? thou dost nothing but interrupt me: I say to be paid, to his said mistress, her executors, or assigns, whensoever she demand it, at the font-stone of the temple —

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Put it, the top of Paul's and please you; your conceit will be the higher.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p:
Which payment to be truly made and performed, I
bind, not my heirs, but my body and soul for ever.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: How your soul sir?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Peace fool, my soul will shift for itself, when I am dead that will be sure enough: — in witness whereof, I have hereunto put my hand and seal, which is a handsome spiny youth, with a bag of money in one hand, a bond in the tother, an indenture between his legs, the last of the first merry month, and in the second year of the reign of King Cupid.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Excellent! but in my opinion, you had better give her possession of your heart, I do not like this owing: faith pluck it out, and deliver it in the presence of us.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Thou talkest like a puisne, I can give her possession of it, by delivery of twopence wrapped up in the wax, 'twill hold in law man; — and how, and how d'ye like it? I could have come over you with verse, but hang ballads, give me poetical prose, every mountebank can time, and make his lines cry twang, though there be no reason in 'em.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: What music have I heard?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Music? O rare!

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: He has Medusa's noble countenance,
His hairs do curl like soft and gentle snakes:
Did ever puppy smile so? or the ass
Better become his ears? o generous beast
Of sober carriage, sure he's valiant too,
Those bloodshot eyes betray him, but his nose
Fishes for commendation.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: What does she mean Jasper?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: D'ye not see her love sir? why she does dote upon you, which makes her talk so madly.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Forsooth I know you are taken with me, alas these things are natural with me, when shall we be married forsooth?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: With your licence sir —

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: D'ye not observe her? you must first procure a licence.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: You shall hear more from me, when I come again — Jasper —Exit Rawbone hastily.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: My heart doth breathe itself upon your hand —Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Your father and master Lodam ▪ —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sir I do love your daughter: — I thought it necessary to acquaint you first, because I would go about the business judicially.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: You oblige us both.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I'll promise you one thing.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: What ▪ s that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I'll bring your daughter no wealth.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Say you so: what then you promise her nothing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But I will bring her that which is greater than wealth.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Myself.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: A fair jointure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, I'll bring her more.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: It shan't need, no woman can desire more of a man.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I can bring her good qualities, if she want any: I ha' travailed for 'em.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The languages.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: You suspect she will want tongue: — let me see — parlez franzois monsieur.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Diggon a cam●ag.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: That's welch.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Pocas palabras.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: That's Spanish.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Troth I have such a confusion of languages in my head, you must e'en take 'em as they come.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: You may speak that more exactly — havelar spagniel signior?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Serge-dubois, — Calli-mancho, et Perpetuana.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p:
There's stuff indeed, since you are so perfect, I'll trust you for the rest. I must refer you sir unto my daughter, if you can win her fair opinion, my consent my happily follow: so
she is in presence —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Mercy madam —Salutes Jane.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: This fellow looks like the principal in usury, and this rat follows him like a pitiful eight in the hundred: — come hither sirrah, your name is chameleon.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: It is too true sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: You did live with master Rawbone.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No sir, I did starve with him, and please you:
I could not live with him.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: How do you like your change?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Never worse.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Master Lodam wants no flesh.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But I do: — I ha' no justice sir, my lean master would eat no meat, and my fat master eats up all — is your worship's house troubled with vermin?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Something at this time.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Peace and I'll catch a mouse then. —Lies down.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: My nephew turned gentleman usher.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sir John Belfare's daughter.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Alas poor gentlewoman,
I compassionate her unkind destiny.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let us entreat a word in private sir —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I cannot tell how you stand affected, but if you can love a man, I know not what is wanting, greatness is a thing that your wisest ladies have an itch after: for my own part I was never in love before, and if you have me not, never will be again. Think on't between this and after dinner, I will stay o'purpose for your answer.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: You're very short.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I would not be kept in expectation above an hour, for love is worse than a lent to me, and fasting is a thing my flesh abhors, if my doublet be not filled, I know who fares the worse for't. I would keep my flesh to swear by, and if you and I cannot agree upon the matter, I would lose nothing by you.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: You're very resolute.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ever while you live, a fat man, and a man of resolution go together: I do not commend myself, but there are no such fiery things in nature.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Fiery?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Tis proved, put 'em to my action, and see, if they do not smoke it, they are men of mettle, and the greatest melters in the world, one hot service makes 'em roast, and they have enough in 'em to baste a hundred — you may take a lean man, marry yourself to famine, and beg for a great belly, you see what became of sir John's daughter: — come I would wish you be well advised, there are more commodities in me, than you are aware of, if you and I couple, you shall fare like an empress.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: That will be somewhat costly.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not a token. I have a privilege: — I was at the tavern tother day, i'the next room I smelled hot venison, I sent but a drawer to tell the company, one in the house with a great belly, longed for a corner, and I had half a pasty sent me immediately: I will hold intelligence with all the cooks i'the town, and what dainty, but I have greatness enough to command?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I like it well: — be as welcome here, as at your fathers. Milisent — make it your care to wait upon this gentlewoman, but conceal she is our guest. I should rejoice to see this storm blown over. — nephew attend her to her chamber. Exeunt Gratiana, captain, Milisent.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I ha' been about it —Justles Lodam, and falls down.

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.p: Next time you ride post, wind your horn, that one may get out a'the way.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: What's the matter Jane.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: 'Tis guts, if I durst, my teeth waters to strike him.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: What ha' you done?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Let him take heed another time.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Take such an affront before your mistress.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I have a good stomach —

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: That's well said.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I could eat him.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: O is it that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Let me alone, nobody hold me.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I'll have an action of battery.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Whoreson mole-catcher —
Come not near me weasel.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Prithee Jasper do not thrust me upon him —
I do not fear you sit.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Again shall I kick thee to pieces.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Let him baffle ye — to him —Haver thrusts him upon him.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I do not fear you.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Jane remove yourself.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Master Rawbone, I am sorry for your hurt. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: She jeers you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: For this time I am content with kicking of thee.

div.stage: As Lodam offers to go out, Haver pulls him back.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: My master desires another word w'ee sir. —
You must fight with him —To Rawbone.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Who I fight?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You spider catcher, ha you not enough? you see I do not draw.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: By this hand, you shall challenge him then, if he dare accept it, I'll meet him in your clothes.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Will ye. Hum — I do not fear you — satisfaction —

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: That's the word.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: That's the word — you'll meet me guts.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Meet thee by this flesh, if thou dost but provoke me: — you do not challenge me — do not — d'ye long to be minced?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: At Finsbury —

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: At Finsbury.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Tomorrow morning —

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Tomorrow morning — you shall find I dare fight.

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.p: Say but such another word.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Finsbury, tomorrow morning, there 'tis again —

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I cannot contain my laughter, ha, ha, ha.Exit

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: So, let's begone quickly, before he threaten me, you made me challenge him, look to't.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Fear not, I warrant you. Exeunt raw and Haver.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sirrah noverint, if I can but prove, thou dost come with in three furlongs of a windmill, I'll set one a top of Paul's to watch thee — shalt forfeit thy soul, and I'll cancel thy body worse than any debtor of thine did his obligation — he's gone — and now I think upon the matter, I have somewhat the worst on't, for if I should kill him, I shall never be able to fly, and he has left a piece of his scull, I think, in my shoulder — whither am I bound to meet him, or no? I will consult some o'the sword men, and know whether it be a competent challenge — chameleon.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Has the rat, your master that was, any spirit in him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Spirit? the last time he was in the field, a boy of seven years old, beat him with a trapstick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sayest thou so? I will meet him then, and hew him to pieces.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I have an humble suit — if it be so, that you kill him, let me beg his body for an anatomy, I have a great mind to eat a piece on him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Tis granted, follow me, I'll cut him up I warrant thee. Exe.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I have a letter.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I would forget that name, speak it no more.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: She is abused, and if you had not been
Transported from us, with your passion,
You would ha' changed opinion, to have heard
How well she pleaded.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: For herself.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You might,
With little trouble gather from her tears
How clear she was, which more transparent, than
The morning dew, or crystal, fell neglected
Upon the ground: some cunning jeweller
To ha' seen 'em scattered, would a thought some Princess
dropped 'em, and covetous to enrich himself,
Gathered them up for diamonds.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You are then converted.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: O you were too credulous.
Marwood has played the villain, and is damned for't ▪
Could but his soul be brought to hear her answer
The accusation, she would make that blush,
And force it to confess a treason, to
Her honour, and your love.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You did believe her.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I did, and promised her to do this service,
She begged of me at parting, if she sent
A letter, to convey it to your hand,
Pray read, you know not what this paper carries.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Has she acquainted you?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Not me, I guess,
It is some secret, was not fit for my
Relation, it may be, worth your knowledge;
Do her that justice, since you would not hear
What she could say in person, to peruse
Her paper.

sp.speaker: Rea.
sp.l: It can bring nothing to take off
Th' offence committed.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Sir you knew not
What satisfaction it contains ▪
Or what she may confess in't ▪ for my sake —Reads ▪

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: To him that was — what?
Confident of her virtue
Once an admirer, now a mourner for
Her absent goodness: she has made the change.
From her that was, would 〈◊〉 become this paper
Had she conserved her first immaculate whiteness,
It had been half profane, not to salute
Her letter with a kiss, and touch it, with
More veneration than a sybil's leaf ▪
but now all ceremony must be held
A superstition, to the blotted scroll,
Oh a more stained writer — I'll not read:
If unprepared, she win with her discourse,
What must she do, when she has time, and study,
To apparel her defence?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Deny her this.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Well, I will read it.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here's sir John Belfare.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Say any thing t'excuse me, beet your care
That none approach the chamber.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: So, so, now unrip the seal.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Not speak with him, he must have stronger guard
To keep me out: where's Beauford?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Then there's a villain.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: That's course language.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I must not spin it finer, till you make me
Understand better, why my daughter, and
In her, my family is abused.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: She has not then accused herself — I'll tell you,
I did expect your daughter would have been
My virgin bride; but she reserved for me
The ruins of her honour, I would not speak
I'the rude dialect, you may sooner collect,
An English.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is she not honest, will you
Make her then a whore?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Not I, her own sin made her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou liest, nor can my age make me appear
Unworthy a satisfaction from thy sword.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Does not he call my young mistress whore?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Keep me not from him captain he has in this
Given a fresh wound, I came t'expostulate,
The reason of a former suffering,
Which unto this was charity, as thou art
A gentleman, I dare thee to the combat:
Contemn not Beauford my grey hairs, if t'hast
A noble soul, keep not this distance; meet me,
Thou art a soldier: for heaven's sake, permit me
Chastise the most uncharitable slander
Of this bad man.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I never injured you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Not injured me? what is there then in nature,
Left, to be called an injury? didst not mock
Me, and my poor fond girl with marriage?
Till all things were designed, the very day
When Hymen should have worn his saffron robe:
My friends invited, and prepared to call
Her bride; and yet, as if all this could not
(Summed up together) make an injury:
Does thy corrupted soul at last conspire
To take her white name from her? — give me leave
To express a father, in a tear, or two,
For my wronged child. O Beauford! thou hast robbed
A father, and a daughter — but I woe not
Usurp heaven's justice, which shall punish thee
'Bove my weak arm; mayst thou live, to have
Thy heart as ill rewarded, to be a father
At my years, have one daughter, and no more
Beloved as mine, so mocked, and then called whore.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Alas good old man. Exit Bel. Isaac.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: My afflictions
Are not yet numbered in my fate, nor I
held ripe for death.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Now read the letter.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Yes, it cannot make me know more misery. Reads.

Beauford, I dare not call thee mine, though I could not hope, (While I was living,) thou wouldst believe my innocence, deny me not this favour after death, to say I once loved thee — ha death? Captain is she dead?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I hope she employed not me, to bring this news.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Yes, death — ha?
Prithee read the rest: there's something
In my eyes, I cannot well distinguish
Her small characters.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: My accuser by this time, knows the reward of my injury farewell, I am carrying my prayers for thee to another world — her own martyr, drowned Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Read all.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: It cannot be, for when thou mak'st an end,
My heart should give a tragic period,
And with a loud sigh break: drowned
'Twas no sin above heaven's pardon ▪
Though thou hadst been false,
To thy first vow, and me, I would not had
Thee died so soon ▪ or if thou hadst affected
That death, I could ha' drowned thee with my tears,
Now they shall never find thee, but be lost
Within thy watery sepulchre.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Take comfort.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Art dead?
Then here I'll coffin up myself, until
The law unbury me for Marwood's death,
I wonot hope for life, mercy shall not save
Him, that hath now a patent for his grave. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quarti. Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: 'Tis his command to whom I owe all service,
I should attend you.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Thou'rt too diligent:
I prithee leave me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I should be unhappy
To be offensive in my duty; yet
Had I no charge upon me, I should much
Desire to wait.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: On me?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I know not why,
Your sorrow does invite me.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Thou'rt too young,
To be acquainted wilt.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I know, it would not
Become my distance, to dispute with you,
At what age, we are fittest to receive
Our grief's impression.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Leave me to myself —

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I must, if you will have it so.Offers to go out.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Methought
I saw him drop a tear, come back again:
What should he mean by this unwillingness
To part; he looks, as he would make me leave
my own misfortune to pity his:
Thy name?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I am called Milisent.

sp.speaker: Grat
sp.l: Dost thou put on that countenance to imitate
Mine? or hast a sorrow of thy own, thou
Wouldst express by't.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Mine does become my fortune.
Yet yours does so exactly paint our misery
That he, that wanted of his own, would mourn
To see your picture.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Mine is above
The common level of affliction.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Mine had no example to be drawn by,
I would they were a kin, so I might make
Your burden less by mine own suffering.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I thank thy love.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And yet I prophesy,
There's something would make mine a part of yours,
Were they examined.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Passion makes thee wild now.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You have encouraged me to boldness, pardon
My ruder language.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Didst thou ever love?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Too soon, from thence sprung my unhappiness.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: My affliction riper than my years,
Hath brought me so much sorrow, I do not think
That I shall live, to be a man.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I like thy sad expression, we'll converse
And mingle storeys.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I shall be too bold.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: We lay aside distinctions, if our fates
Make us alike in our misfortunes; yet
Mine will admit no parallel: ha! we are interrupted:
Let's withdraw, and I'll begin.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You may command, and when
Your storeys done, mine shall maintain the scene. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Justice
