sp.l: To maintain such bliss I will,
Wish to be transformed still:
Nor wilt be a shame in love,Reads,
Since I imitate but Jove;
Who from heaven hath strayed, and in
A thousand figures worse than mine,
Wooed a virgin, may not I,
Then for thee a servant try:
Yes for such a maid as thee,
Vary as many shapes as he;
Rawbone clothes my outward part,
But thy livery my heart:
Haver, ha: young Haver?
sp.p: This letter I found in my daughter's prayer book, is this your saint? how long ha' they conspired thus? Report gave out, he was gone to travail: it seems he stays here for a wind, and in the mean time would rig up my daughter: he is a gentleman well educated; but his fortune was consumed by a prodigal father, ere he was ripe, which makes him I suspect; borrow this shape to court my daughter; little does Rawbone think his servant is his rival: I find the juggling, and will take order they sha'not steal a marriage.
sp.l: Nephew, I ha' news for you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: For me sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: You are a soldier, there's a duel to
Be fought this morning, will you see't?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: It does not sir become a gentleman
To be spectator of a fight, in which
He's not engaged.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: You may behold it cousin,
Without disparagement to your honour; Rawbone
Has challenged Mr. Lodam, the place Finsbury —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: They fight? A doublet, stuffed with straw, advancing
A bulrush, were able to fright 'em both
Out a'their senses, tha' not soul enough
To skirmish with a fieldmouse; they point a duel?
At Hogs-don, to show fencing upon cream
And cakebread, murder a quaking custard,
Or some such daring enemy.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Did not
Affairs of weight compel me to be absent,
I would not miss the sight, on't; for the usurer
Hath got his man Jasper t'appear for him
In his apparel.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Jasper.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: For mirth's sake
You may behold it, and let me entreat,
At your return, perfect relation
Of both their valours.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You shall sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: And coz —
If it be possible, procure 'em hither
Before they shift, I much desire to see 'em.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Promise yourself they shall: I will defer
My conference with Gratiana, and
Entertain this recreation.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: So: I have a fancy,
This opportunity will give it birth,
If all hit right, it may occasion mirth. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Which part of my discourse compels thee to
This suffering?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Your pardon lady, I
Did prophesy what now I find, our storeys
Have dependence

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: How prithee?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: That Marwood
Whom you report thus wounded had a near
relation to me, and 'twas my fortune
To come to close his eyes up, and receive
His last breath.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I know more than Beauford,
And dying he obliged my love to tell t'him
When ere we met.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You beget wonder in me:
Did he survive his slander? there is hope
He did recant the injury he did me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He did confirm, he had enjoyed your person,
And bade me tell Beauford he left behind
A living witness of the truth he died for:
Naming a gentlewoman Cardona,
That bred you in your father's house, whom he
Affirmed, betrayed your body to his lust.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Cardona?
Piety has forsaken earth:
Was ever woman thus betrayed to sin,
Without her knowledge?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Would he had not been
My kinsman, I begin to fear him:

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Wherein had I offended Marwood,
He should alive, and dead so persecute
My fame? Cardona too i'the conspiracy,
'Tis time to die then.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: My heart mourns for you
In the assurance of your innocence,
And were I worthy to direct you —

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Has, malice
Found out another murderer?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Would you be pleased to hear me, I could point
You out a path, would bring you no repentance
To walk in, if (As I am confident)
Your goodness fears not, what Cardona can
accuse your honour with, let her be
Examined, then her knowledge will quit you,
Or make your suffering appear just, this is
An easy trial, and since Marwood had
A stubborn soul, for though he were my kinsman
I prefer justice, and held ●ham to check
His own report, women have softer natures,
And things may be so managed, if there be
A treason, to enfroce confession from her:
Would you please t'imploy me in this service,
And though unworthy be directed by me,
I beg it from you, I'll engage my being
You shall find comfort in't.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Do any thing;
But I am lost already.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You much honour me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come, see and if he be come yet, bring me word hither.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I see one lying o'the ground —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is there so? let's steal way before we be discovered, I do not like when men lie perdieu, beside, there may be three or four of a heap, for ought we know: let's back I say.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis a horse.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hang him jade, I knew it could be nothing else: is the coast clear chameleon?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I see nothing but five or six.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Five or six: treachery! an ambush, 'tis valour to run.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: They be windmill.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And yet, thou wod'st persuade me, 'twas an ambush for me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Come thou wert afraid, and the truth were known; but be valiant: I have a sword; and if I do draw ▪ it shall — be against my will: is he not come yet?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And he were between this and More-gate, you might scent him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: If he come, somebody shall smell ill favouredly, ere he and I part: — ha! by this ●●●sh 'tis he; Cam, go tell him I am sick.

div.stage: Enter haver, Rawbone, (Having changed clothes) captain.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Master Lodam.

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.p: A brace of bullets to my hair.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Here can I stand and behold the champions.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I have expected you this two hours, which is more than I had one to all the men I ha' fought withal, since I slew the high German in Tutle.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Whorson, mole-catcher.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Draw spider.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Wellslye toad.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Let us confer a little.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Confer me no conferrings: I will have no more mercy on thee, than an infidel: and t'hadst been wise, thou mightest ha' kept thee at home, with thy melancholy cat, that keeps thy study, with whom thou art in commons, and dost feed on rats a Sundays; then perhaps a leg or an arm, with thy Jews ears had satisfied me, when I met thee next: draw I say, why dost not draw?

sp.speaker: Hau
sp.p: I come to give you satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What with words?

Sirrah Tartar, my fox shall scratch thy guts out, which I will send to the bear-garden: dost hear usuring dog, I'll tell thee my resolution. I do mean to give thee as many wounds before I kill thee, as a surgeon's sign has; and when I am weary of skarrifying thy flesh, I'll bore thy heart — which done: mark what I say; I will divide thy quarters: observe and tremble; then will I ha' thee put into a tub or barrel, and powder thee, and after three days in pickle, this thing that was thy servant, this cacodaemon whom thou didst statue once, chameleon, shall in revenge of his pitiful famine, eat thee up, devour thee, and grow fat i'the ribs again with thy flesh. Mammon —

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I hungrily thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: What have I scaped?Aside.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Which is more, after thou art dead, I wonot leave thy
soul quiet, I'll torment thy ghost: for I will straight to thy house where I will break open thy chests, lined with white and yellow mettle, which I will cast away on pious uses: then summon all thy debtors by a drum, and give 'em in, all their bills, bonds, evidences, indentures, defeasances, mortgages, statutes.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I shall be undone. —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And there were a million on 'em.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I'll home, and shut up my doors, for fear he kill Jasper and use me so indeed.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: If thou dost offer to look home again, till they ha' done, I'll cut thee off at thigh.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Ah —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Draw I say.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Since there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: His sword appears Cam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If he were a coward you were able to conjure a spirit into him, with those threatenings.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Pox a'my dulues: dost hear scoundrel, if I should incline to mercy, what submission? ha? let me see — I, ay, live, thou shalt upon thy knees confess thy rascality, and ask me forgiveness in private, in the presence of mistress Jane, and the twelve companies which at thy charge shall be feasted that day, in Morefields.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: That must not be.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Then say when thou art dead, thou wert offered conditions for thy life: Cam, thou shalt feed, and feed high chameleon, — let me see; — come 'tis my foolish nature to ha' compassion o'thee, I know thou'rt sorry, shalt only confess thyself a rascal under thy hand then, and stay my in ended revenge which else would ha' been immortal.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Let me consider.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Oh●cam. —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Both cowards, we shall have no skirmish.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p:
Now I think on't, what if my man Jasper, should be valiant and kill Lodam — umh? what pickle were I in: worse-worse, he'll run away, I shall be taken and hanged for the conspiracy. Pulls have, by the sleeve. r
Ah — Jasper, rogue that I was, where were my brains to challenge him — he wonot hear — a stubborn knave, he looks as if he meant to kill: ah Jasper.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I ha' seen a dog look like him, that has drawn a wicker bottle, rattling about the streets, and leering on both sides, where to get a quiet corner to bite his tail off.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I do imagine myself apprehended already: now the constable is carrying me to Newgate — now, now ▪ I me at the session's house, i'the dock: — now I'm called — not guilty my lord: — the jury has found the indictment billa vera — now, now comes my sentence.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I am resolved sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Ha. —

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: You shall have what acknowledgement, this pen of steel will draw out in your flesh, with red ink, and no other, dear master Lodam.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: So, so.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Now I'm i'the cart, riding up Holborn in a two wheeled chariot, with a guard of halberdiers: there goes a proper fellow says one: good people pray for me: now I am at the three wooden stilts. —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Is this Rawbone the coward?
Dost hear thing — consider what thou dost, come among friends, thy word shall be as good as a note under thy hand, 〈◊〉 not my fury — would I were off, with asking him forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Hey! now I feel my toes hang i'the cart:
Now 'tis drawn away, now, now, now,
I am gone —Turns above.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: You must show your fencing.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hold: I demand a parley.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Tis not for your reputation to deal with a
Gentleman upon unequal terms.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Where lie the odds?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Lod
sp.p: Examine our bodies:
I take it I am the fairer mark, 'tis a disadvantage: feed till you be as fat as I, and I'll fight w'ee as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: It sha' not serve your turn. Fight.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hold, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: I'm dead, I'm dead.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Whoreson puff-paste, how he winks and barks: how now gentlemen, master Lodam.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Captain, should a come but a little sooner, and ha' seen good sport, by this flesh he came up handsomely to me; a pretty spark faith captain.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But if you be his friend, run for a surgeon for him, I have hurt him under the short ribs, beside a cut or two ith' shoulder: would I were in a millars sack yonder, though I were ground for't, to be quit onem.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: You wonot use me thus?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I were best deliver my sword ere I be compelled to't — a pretty fellow, and one that will make a soldier, because I see thou'st a spirit, and canst use thy weapon, I'll bestow a dull blade upon thee squirrel.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Deliver up your weapon:

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: In love in love captain, he's a spark a my reputation, and worthy your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Thou mully-puff, were it not justice to kick thy guts out.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: When I am disarmed.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Take't, again you sponge —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What? when I have geent thee: 'tis at thy service, and it were a whole cutler's shop: be confident.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: My ague has not left me yet ▪ there's a grudging a'the halter still:

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Master Rawbone, I repent my opinion of your cowardice.
I see you dare fight, and shall report it to my cousin:
You shall walk home, she'll take it as an honour,
And present your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Jasper, let's go home and shift, do not go — honest Jasper.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: You will be prattling sirrah — I'll wait upon you captain: master Lodam —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I will accompany thee, thou'rt noble, and fit for my conversation, honest master Rawbone — a pox upon you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nay, you shall wait a your master with his leave, good Jasper

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: How now Jasper? Exeunt.

div.stage: Music: a table set forth with two tapers: servants placing ewe, bays, and rosemary, etc.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Are these the herbs you strew at funerals.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I commend your care,
And thank ye; ye have expressed more duty
In not enquiring wherefore I command
This strange employment, there in the very
Act of your obedience: my chamber
Looks like the spring now? ha' ye not art enough
To make this ewe ●ee grow here, or this bays?
The emblem of our victory in death?
But they present that best when they are withered:
Have you been careful that no day break in
At any window, I would dwell in night,
And have no other starlight but these tapers:

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: If any ask to speak with you,
Shall I say, you are abroad.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: No, to all do inquire with busy faces
Pale or disturbed, give free access. Exit Ser.
What do I differ from the dead? would not
Some fearful man or woman seeing me,
call this a churchyard, and imagine me
Some wakeful apparition among the graves;
That for some treasures buried in my life,
Walk up and down thus? buried? no 'twas drowned,
I cannot therefore say, it was a chest,
Gratiana had ne'er a coffin, I have one
Spacious enough for both on's, but the waves
Will never yield to't, for it may be they
Soon as the Northern wind blows cold upon 'em,
Will freeze themselves to marble over her,
Lest she should want a tomb:
Thy business.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: He died this morning:
A friend of his and yours did practise on him
A little surgery, but in vain; his last
Breath did forgive you: but you must expect
No safety from the law: my service sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I have left direction, that it cannot miss me:
And hadst thou come to apprehend me for't?
With as much ease thou mightst; I am no statesman
Officious, servants makes no suitors wait
My doors unguarded; 'tis no labyrinth
I dwell in; but I thank thy love, there's something
To reward it: justice cannot put on
A shape to fright me.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: I am sorry sir,
Your resolution carries so much danger. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What can life bring to me, that I should court it:
There is a period in nature, is't not
Better to die and not be sick; worn in
Our bodies, which in imitation
Of ghosts, grow lean, as if they wooed at last
Be immaterial too; our blood turn jelly
And freeze in their cold channel, let me expire
while I have heat and strength to tug with death
For victory.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You may disburden there,
But gently, 'tis a chest of value, mistress —
I'll give him notice, where is Beauford?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: What place d'ye call this?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: 'Tis a bridal chamber.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: It presents horror.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha you anything
To say to me?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You are not welcome then.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I did suspect it, and have therefore brought
My assurance wi'me, I must require
Satisfaction for a kinsman's death,
One Marwood.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Your valour was not noble,
It was a course reward to kill him for
His friendship: I come not with a guard of
Officers to attach your person, it
Were too poor and formal, the instrument
That sluiced his soul out, I had rather should
Sacrifice to his ashes, and my sword
Shall do't, or yours be guilty of another,
To wait upon his ghost.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Young man be not
Too rash without the knowledge how our quarrel
Rise to procure thyself a danger.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Make it
Not your fear, I have heard the perfect story,
And ere I fight with thee shalt see thy error;
Acknowledge thou hast killed a friend, I bring
A perspective to make those things that lie
Remote from sense, familiar to thee, nay
Thou shalt confess thou knowest the truth of what
Concerns him, or Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: When my soul
Throws off this upper garment, I shall know all.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Thou shalt not number many minutes, know
'Twas my misfortune to close up the eyes
Of Marwood, whose body I vowed never
Should to the earth without revenge; or me
Companion to his grave: I ha' therefore brought it
Hither, 'tis in this house.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: His pale corpses
Shall witness my affection.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thou didst promise
To inform me of Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And thus briefly:
Marwood revealed at death another witness
Of his truth, for Cardona he corrupted
To betray Gratiana to him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha Cardona!
Heaven continue her among the living,
But half an hour.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I ha' saved ye trouble,
She waits without, in your name I procured
Her presence, as you had affairs with her
She's unprepared, a little terror will
Enforce her to confess the truth of all things.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Thou dost direct well.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Still remember Beauford
I am thy enemy, and in this do but
Prepare thy conscience of misdeed to
Meet my just anger.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I am all wonder. Milisent bring in Cardona.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He's now at opportunity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sir you sent
To speak with me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Come nearer, I hear say
You are bawd; tell me how go virgins
I'th sinful market; nay I must know hell-cat
What was the price you took for Gratiana's:
Did Marwood come off roundly with his wages ▪
Tell me the truth, or by my father's soul
I'll dig thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Help.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Let me not hear
A syllable that has not reference
To my question — or —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'll tell you sir:
Marwood —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Did viciously affect her:
Won with his gifts and flatteries, I promised
My assistance, but I knew her virtue was not
To be corrupted in a thought.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Therefore —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What d'ye study —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hold — I would deliver
The rest into your ear, it is too shameful
To express it louder than a whisper —

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: With what unwillingness, we discover things
We are ashamed to own: Cardona shouldst
Ha used but half this fear in thy consent.
And thou hadst ne'er been guilty of a sin
thou art so loath to part with though it be
A burden to thy soul: how boldly would
Out innocence plead for us; but she's done.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Then was Gratiana's honour saved.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Untouched.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Where am I lost: this story is more killing
Than all my jealousies: o Cardona
Go safe from hence, but when thou comest at home,
Lock thyself up and languish, till thou die
Thou shalt meet Marwood, in a gloomy shade,
Give back this salary,Exit Cardona.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Have I made good
My promise, do you find your error.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: No I ha' found my horror — has the chaste
And innocent Gratiana drowned herself?
What satisfaction can I pay thy ghost?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Now do me right sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: She's gone for ever,
And can the earth still dwell a quiet neighbour
To the rough sea, and not itself be thawed
Into a river; let it melt to waves
From henceforth, that beside th'inhabitants,
The very genius of the world may drown,
And not accuse me for her: o Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Reserve your passion, and remember what
I come for.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: How shall I punish my unjust suspicion?
Death is too poor a thing to suffer for her ▪
Some spirit guide me where her body lies
Within her watery urn, although sealed up
With frost, my tears are warm and can dissolve it,
To let in me, and my repentance to her.
I would kiss her cold face into life again
Renew her breath with mine, on her pale lip
I do not think, but if some artery
of mine were opened, and the crimson flood
Conveyed into her veins, it would agree
And with a gentle gliding steal itself
Into her heart, enliven her dead faculties,
And with a flattery, 'tice her soul again,
To dwell in her fair tenement.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You lose
Yourself in these wild fancies; recollect
And do me justice.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I am lost indeed,
With fruitless passion: I remember thee
And thy design again; I must account
For Marwood's death is't not? alas thou art
Too young, and canst not fight, I wish thou wert
A man of tough and active sinews, for
Thy own revenge' sake, I would praise thee for
My death, so I might fall but nobly by thee:
For I am burdened with a weight of life —
Stay, didst not tell me thou hadst brought hither
The body of young Marwood —

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Since a mistake, not malice did procure
His ill fate, I will but drop one funeral
Tear upon his wound, and soon finish
To do thee right.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Ye shall. A coffin brought in.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Does this enclose his corpses? how little room
Do we take up in death, that living, know
No bounds? here without murmuring we can
Be circumscribed, it is the soul, that makes us
Affect such wanton, and irregular paths;
When that's gone, we are quiet as the earth,
And think no more of wand'ring: o Marwood
Forgive my anger, thy confession did
Invite thy ruin from me, yet upon —Opens.
My memory forsake me, 'tis Gratiana's
Spirit, hast thou left thy heavenly dwelling
To call me hence? I was now coming to thee:
Or but command more haste, and I will count it
No sin to strike myself, and in the stream
Of my own blood to imitate how thou
Didst drown thyself.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I am living Beauford.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: I know thou art immortal.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Living as thou art.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Good angels do not mock mortality.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: And came —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: To call me to my answer how I durst
Suspect thy chastity, I'll accuse myself
And to thy injured innocence give me up
A willing sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: O my Beauford, now
I am overblessed for my late sufferings;
I have solicited my death with prayers:
Now I would live to see my Beauford love me.
It was thy friend induced me to that letter,
To find if thy suspicion had destroyed
All seeds of love.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Art thou not dead indeed,
May I believe? her hands is warm, — she breathes
Again — and kisses as she wont to do
Her Beauford, art Gratiana? Heaven
Let me dwell here until my soul exhale.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: One sorrow's cured Milisent begone,
Thou hast been too long absent from thy own. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O my joy ravished soul, but where's the youth
Brought me this blessing? vanished Gratiana
Where is he? I would hang about his neck
And kiss his cheek, he we not leave me so:
Gone? sure it was some angel, was he not,
or do I dream this happiness, wot not thou
Forsake me to?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: O never.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Within there —
Bid the young man return, and quickly, lest
My joy above the strength of nature's sufferance,
Kill me before I can express my gratitude:
Ha ye brought him?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Mr. Beauford, I am sorry we are
Commanded to apprehend your person.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Officers ha?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: You are suspected to have slain a
Gentleman, one Marwood.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Have I still my essence ha?
I had a joy was able to make man
Forget he could be miserable.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: If ere extremities did kill, we hath
Shall die this very minute.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You sha'not go.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.l: Our authority will force him.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You're villains, murderers:
O my Beauford!

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Leave me Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Never, I'll die with thee.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: What can we say unto our misery,
Saved in a tempest that did threaten most,
Arrived the harbour, ship, and all are lost.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: To the next justice. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quinti. Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Whether art fled Gratiana? that I can
Converse with none to tell me thou art still
A mortal? taken hence by miracle?
Though angels should entice her hence, to heaven,
She was so full of piety, to her father,
She would first take her leave.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: There he is sir, he cannot choose but talk idly,
For he has not slept since the last great mist.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: M●st?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ay sir ▪ his daughter, my young mistress went away in't, and we can hear no tale nor tidings of her, to tell you true, I would not disgrace my old master, but he is little better than mad.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Unhappy gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis so, he murdered her;
For he that first would rob her of her honour,
Would or fear afterwards to kill Gratiana,
He shall be arranged for't; — but where shall we
Get honest men enough to make a jury?
That dare be conscionable, when the judge
Looks on, and frowns upon the verdict, men
That will not be corrupted, to favour
A great man evidence, but prefer justice
To ready money? O this age is barren —

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Master Beauford's newly
Apprehended for some fact, and carried
Fore justice Landby, in my passage hither
I met him guarded.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Guarded for what?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Some did whisper he had killed —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Gratiana.
sp.p: O my girl, my Gratiana, — Isaac, Beauford is taken, 'tis apparent he hath slain my daughter, and sha'not I revenge her death? I'll prosecute the law with violence against him, not leave the judge, till he pronounce his sentence, then I'll die, and carry Gratiana the news before him. Follow me ▪Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I expect Jane thou wot reward my care
With thy obedience, he's young and wealthy,
No matter for those idle ceremonies
Of wit and courtship.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Do I hear my father?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: He will maintain thee gallant, city wives
Are fortune's darlings, govern all, their husband's
Variety of pleasure, and apparel
When some of higher title are oft fain
To pawn a ladyship: thou shalt have Rawbone.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Virtue forbid it, you are my father sir,
And lower than the earth I have a heart
Prostrates itself, I had my being from you,
But I beseech you, take it not away
Again, by your severity.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: How's this? I like it well.Aside.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: You have read many lectures to me, which
My duty hath received, and practised, as
Precepts from heaven, but never did I hear
You preach so ill, you heretofore directed
my study to be careful of my fame,
Cherish desert, plant my affection on
Nobleness, which can only be sufficient
To make it fruitful, and d'ye counsel now
To marry a disease?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Good! my own girls —
What is't you said? ha?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: For the man himself
Is such a poor and miserable thing —

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: But 〈◊〉 another word, and I take off
My blessing: how now Jane?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: 〈◊〉, I fear
He is in earnest, marry me to my grave,
To that you shall have my consent, o do not
Enforce me to be guilty of a false
Vow, both to heaven and angels; on my knees —

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Humble your heart, 〈◊〉 and correct your sullenness,
I am resolved, would you be sacrificed
To an unthrift, that will 〈◊〉 away his skin,
Rather than want to stake at ordinaries?
Consume what I have gathered at a breakfast,
Or morning's draught? and when you ha' teemed for him
Turn semptress to find milk and clouts for babies:
Foot stockings, to maintain him in the compter?
Or if this fail, erect a bandy citadel,
Well maned, which fortified with demi-canon
Tobacco pipes, may raise you to a fortune,
Together with the trail —

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: O my cruel stars!

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Star me no stars, I'll have my will —

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: One minute hath ruined all my hope, Milisent
Was cruel thus to mock me.

div.stage: Enter captain, Haver, Lodam, Rawbone, and Cameleon.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Unde —Cap. and just, whisper.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You hear, now he talks.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But I ha' found the way, 'tis but procuring
Acquaintance with the foreman of the jury,
The session's bell-wether, he leads the rest
Like sheep when he makes a gap, they follow
In huddle to his sentence.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Speak to him sir.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: God save you sir John Belfare.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am a little serious — do not trouble me.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: D'ye not know me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I neither know, nor care for you, unless
You can be silent.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: I me your neighbour —

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Master doctor —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Away fool.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: No sir, a physician.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A physician? can you cure my daughter?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Ay sir, where is she?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Cannot you find her out by art? A good
Physician, should be acquainted with the stars:
Prithee erect a figure, grave astronomer,
Shalt ha' the minute she departed; turn
Thy Ephemerides a little, I'll lend
Thee Ptolemy, and a nest of learned rabbis
To judge by: tell me whether she be a live,
Or dead, and thou shalt be my doctor, I'll
Give thee a round per annum pension,
And thou shalt kill me for it.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: He has a strange de lyrium.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Ay sir.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: A vertigo in's head.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: In his head.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What says the raven?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: He says, you have two hard words in your head sir.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Have you forgotten me sir, I was but late
familiar to your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.l: Ha' your pardon gentle sir I know you now,
Impute it to my grief, t'hath almost made me
Forget myself.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: I come to visit you.
And cannot but be sorry, to behold
You thus afflicted.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Doctor I am sick,
I'm very sick at heart loss of my daughter
I fear, will make me mad, how long d'ye think
Man's nature able to resist it, can
Your love or art prescribe your friend a cordial?
No, no, you cannot.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Sir, be comforted.
We have our manly virtue given us,
To exercise in such extremes as these.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As these? why do you know what 'tis to
Lose a daughter? you converse with men, that
Are diseased in body; punished with a gout
Or fever: yet some of these are held
The shames of physic, but to th'mind you can
Apply no salutary medicine:
My daughter sir, my daughter —

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Was too blame
To leave you so, lose not your wisdom for
Your daughter's want of piety.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Speak well
A'th dead, for living she would not be absent
Thus from me, she was ever dutiful
Took pleasure in obedience: o my child,
But I have strong suspicion, by whom
She's made away. Beauford —

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.l: He that pretended marriage — he gave her
A wound before.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Jasper? what case am I in?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Be wise and keep your counsel, is not all for your honour?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Lady 〈…〉 by this time, you are able to distinguish
A difference 〈◊〉 Rawbone and myself.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I find 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You shall do noble sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Mr. Rawbone, the only man in my wishes:
My nephew gives you valiant, your merit
O'erjoys me, and to show how much I value
Your worth my daughter yours, I'll see you
Married this morning ere we part, receive him
Into your bosom Jane, or lose me ever.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I obey sir: will my father cozen himself?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Ha, do I dream?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Dream quotha, this is a pretty dream.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Master Lodam, I hope you'll not repine at his fortune.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: But Rawbone will pine, and repine if this be not a dream?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I allow it ▪ and will dine with you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Jasper: no, will nobody know me?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Let's lose no time, I have no quiet tell
I call him son.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Master justice, do me right,
You do not know who I am — I am —

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: An ass sir, are you not? what make you prattling?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Sir, —
Noble captain, a word, I am —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: A coxcomb.
Your man is fancy sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Then I am a — sleep.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I forget Gratiana

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Cousin, you shall supply my place at church, while I prepare for your return, some guests we must have — nay, nay haste, the morn grows old, we'll have't a wedding day.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Here's a blessing beyond hope.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Sure I am sleep, I will cene walk with 'em till my dream be out.

div.stage: Enter Beuford, officers, Marwood disguised, keeper, Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Mr. Beauford, welcome and Gratiana —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: You will repent your courtesy, I am
Presented an offender to you.

sp.speaker: Off●.
sp.l: Yes, and please your worship, he is accused.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Sir, you have charity, believe 'em not,
They do conspire to take away his life.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: May it please you understand, he has killed
A gentleman, one Marwood, in our park,
I found him wounded mortally, though before
He died, he did confess.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Urge it no farther,
I'll save the trouble of examination,
And yield myself up guilty.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: For heaven's sake
Believe him not, he is an enemy
To his own life; dear Beauford, what d'ye mean
To cast yourself away, you're more unmerciful
Than those that do accuse you, than the law
Itself, for at the worst, that can but find
You guilty at the last, too soon for me
To be divided from you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: O Gratiana, I call heaven to witness,
Though my misfortune made me think before,
My life a tedious and painful trouble,
My very soul a luggage, and too heavy
For me to carry, now I wish to live,
To live for thy sake, till my hair were silvered
With age; to live till thou wouldst ha' me die,
And were a weary of me: for I never
Could by the service of one life, reward
Enough thy love, nor by the suffering
The punishment of age and time, do penance
Sufficient for my injury, but my fate
Hurries me from thee, then accept my death
A satisfaction for that sin, I could not
redeem alive, I cannot but confess
The accusation.

div.stage: Enter sir John Belfare, and Isaac.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Justice, justice, I will have justice:
Ha Gratiana!

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: O my dear father —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Art a live, o my joy, it grows
Too mighty for me, I must weep a little
To save my heart —

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My young mistress alive.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: If ever you loved Gratiana, plead for Beauford,
Has been abused, by a villain, all's discovered,
We've renewed hearts, and now I fear, I shall
Lose him again, accused here for the death
Of Marwood, that was cause of all our suffering.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I ha' not wept enough for joy Gratiana
That thou'rt alive yet — I understand nothing
Beside this comfort.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Dear sir recollect,
And second me.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: The fact confessed, all hope
Will be a pardon sir may be procured:
Sir John — you're come in a sad time.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What is the worst you charge him with?

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: He has slain a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: No common trespass.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: He has done justice.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: A public benefit to his country in't.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Killing a man? her sorrow overthrows
Her reason.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Hear me, Marwood was a villain,
A rebel unto virtue, a profaner
Of friendships sacred laws, a murderer
Of virgin chastity, against whose malice
no innocence could hope protection;
But like a 〈…〉 by an eagle's talon,
It growing dies.
What punishment can you inflict on him,
That in contempt of nature, and religion,
Enforces breach of love, of holy vows?
Sets them at war whose hearts were married
In a 〈◊〉 congregation of angels:
I know you will not say, but such deserve
To die yet Marwood being dead, you reach
Your fury to his heart, that did this benefit.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: O Gratiana if I may not live
To 〈◊〉 thee here, il would thou hadst been dead
Indeed so in a little time, we should
〈…〉 each other in a better world?
But since I go before thee, I will carry
Thy 〈◊〉 along, and if my soul forget not,
What it hath 〈◊〉, when it conversed with men,
I will so talk of thee among the blessed.
That they shall be in love with thee, and descend
In holy shapes, to woe thee to come thither,
And be of their society do not 〈◊〉 thy beauty
With such a shower, keep this soft rain,
To water some more lost, and barren garden,
Lest thou destroy the spring, which nature made
To be a wonder in thy cheek

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Where is Marwood's body?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A live!

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Ha Marwood?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A live, as glad to see thee, as thou art
To know thyself 〈◊〉 for my 〈◊〉;
Which I of purpose by this honest friend,
To whose cure, I owe my life, made you believe,
I increase our joy at meeting: for you lady,
you are a woman, — yet you might ha' been
Less violent in your pleading, do not
Engage me passed respects of mine, or your own honour.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Mine is above thy malice, I have a breast
Impenetrable, 'gainst which, thou sound aiming,
Thy arrows, but recoil into thy bosom,
And leave a wound.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Friend we have found thy error —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let it be mine, we have had storms already.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Tell me injurious man for in this presence
You must acquit the honour you accused,
Discharge thy poison here, in humane traitor —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Thou wilt ask her now forgiveness , she's all chastity.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why d'ye tempt me thus?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It was ill done sir —

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Accuse her to her face.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So so, you see, I am silent still.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: You are too full of guilt to excuse your treachery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then farewell all respect, and hear me tell
This bold and insolent woman, that so late
Made triumph in my death.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: O sir proceed not,
You do not declare yourself of generous birth,
Thus openly to accuse a gentlewoman,
Were it a truth.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: He may throw soil at heaven,
And as soon stain it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sirrah boy, who made you so peremptory
He would be whipped.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: With what? I am not armed
You see, but your big language would not fright
My youth, were it be friended with a sword;
You should find than I would dare to prove it
A falsehood , on your person.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: How now Milisent?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hath my love made me thus ridiculous?
Beauford, that you will suffer such a boy
To affront me? then against all the world
I rise an enemy, and defy his valour
Dares justify Gratiana virtuous.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Believe your eyes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My daughter alive?
O my dear heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are come opportunely,
Cardona speak the truth, as thou wouldst not
Eat my poinard, is not Gratiana
A sinful woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What means Marwood, ha?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am in a labyrinth?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hold, I confess —
You never did enjoy Gratiana.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Let not our shame be public, sir, you shall
Have the whole truth, o that my tears were able
To wash my sin away — won with your promises,
I did, in hope to mark myself a fortune,
And get a husband for my child, with much
Black oratory, woe my daughter to
Supply Gratiana's bed, whom with what
Circumstance, you enjoyed, that you believed
It was the virgin you desired.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am at a confasion, where's this daughter?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: She with the fear (As I conceive) of her
Dishonour, taking a few jewels with her,
Went from me, I know not whither, by this time
Dead if not more unhappy in her fortune.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Into how many sins hath lust engaged me?
Is there a hope you can forgive, and you,
and she whom I have most dishonoured
I never had a conscience till now,
To be grieved for her, I will hide myself
From all the world.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Stay sir —

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You hear this Beauford, father —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: This she confessed to me, though I concealed
From thee the error, Marwood dead, their shame
Would not ha' given my life advantage, now
We have o'ercome the malice of our fate:
I hope you'll call me son.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Both my loved children.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I congratulate your joy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Beauford, gentlemen,
This is a woman, Lucibol your daughter,
The too much injured maid: o pardon me,
Welcome both to my knowledge, and my heart.

sp.speaker: Car
sp.l: O my child.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: My servant prove a woman?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You le marry her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall begin my recompense:
Lea● you to church we'll find the priest more work.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: He has done some already, for by this time
I have a daughter married to young Haver.
That walked in Rawbone's livery, — they're returned.

div.stage: Enter captain, Haver, Jane, Lodam, and Cameleon.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: Father your pardon, though you meant me not
Your son, yet I must call your daughter, wife:
Here I resign my citizen.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Young Haver.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: My blessing on you both,
I meant it so: a letter took off this
Disguise before; nay here are more couples,
Enough to play at barleybreak ▪

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Master Lodam, you and I are in hell,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.l: You and I are friends.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I knew, by instinct, I had no quarrel to thee:
Art thou Rawbone?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I am not drunk —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No, but thou art disguised shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I wonot believe, I am awake:
This is not possible.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Leave off to wonder captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Sure this is a dream.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: As sure, as you are there captain, alas we do but walk and talk in our sleep, all this while.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I to dinner bullies.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: D'ye hear gentlemen, before you go, does nobody know me? who am I? who am I?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: You are master Rawbone fit, that would have married my daughter, that is now wise, I take it, to this gentleman, your seeming servant.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Dream on, dream on: Jasper, make much a'the wench now thou'st got her, am not I finely gulled?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Dream on together, a good jest i'faith, he thinks all this is true now.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Are not you then, awake fit?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: No marry am I not sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What d'ye think a' that sir.Kicks him.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: That sir? now do I dream that I am kicked.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You do not feel it then.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Kick, kick your hearts out.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Say you so, let my foot be in too then.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Sure I shall cry out in my sleep — what a long night 'tis.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Set on.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we may come back, and take him napping.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.l: Come Gratiana,
my soul best half, let's tie the sacred knot,
So long deferred, never did two lovers,
Meet in so little time so many changes;
Our wedding day is come, the sorrows past
Shall give our present joy more heavenly taste. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rawbone.
sp.p: Gentlemen: pray he favourable to wake a fool Dormant I mongst ye; ● ha' been kicked, and kick to that purpose, may be, they knocked at the wrong door, my brains are asleep in the garret ▪ I must appeal from their feet to your hands, there is no way but one, you must clap me, and clap me soonly d'ye hear ▪ I shall hardly come to myself else.

lg.l: O since my case without you desperate stands,
Wake me with the loud music of your hands.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
